body:
Thanks for the report @marcusrbrown. This is not a bug, it's intended that using a feature flag like `unstable_ts_config` after it's no longer needed results in an error. Feature flags are used to activate experimental features that could change anytime, also during a minor release like ESLint v9.18.0.

I think in your case you could simply amend the Renovate PR and remove `--flag unstable_ts_config` from the ESLint command:

https://github.com/bfra-me/renovate-action/blob/041f11ba5bec4d080de4ba94497194135d4ee749/package.json#L15 

Am I missing something?

I will amend the dozen repos that cannot be built after 9.18. I disagree that completing the feature behind the flag should mean using the flag results in error - the feature itself remains unchanged between minor versions.

issue.title: Add graceful handling of inactive flags

labels.name: core
labels.description: Relates to ESLint's core APIs and features

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    Thank you for contributing!

    ESLint adheres to the [OpenJS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://eslint.org/conduct).
-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md).

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofix to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[ ] Add something to the core
[x] Other, please explain:

Behavioral change to allow the use of inactive flags, which raise just a warning instead of erring out immediately. This allows people to gracefully migrate their code at their own convenience.

Alternatively flags could be split further into `inactiveFlags` and `removedFlags` for a more complete deprecation schema, although removing them from `inactiveFlags` in a next major also seems very reasonable to me.

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/latest/contribute/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Flags are now filtered, so that inactive flags are removed with a user-facing warning, instead of throwing an error and failing altogether.

Fixes #19337

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

- API used to raise the warning
- Wording of the message

<!-- markdownlint-disable-file MD004 -->

body:
@eslint/eslint-tsc I think it's worth revisiting the behavior of inactive flags. I had previously brought this up on https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/19100#issuecomment-2457741994, where I suggested that the migration path of flags from unstable to stable to removed may be a bit too sharp. I think it makes sense to emit a warning in these situations instead of erroring:

* I think it's reasonable that an unstable flag that is removed because the feature has been merged into HEAD.
* Similarly, when a flag moves from unstable to stable (as in `unstable_foo` -> `v10_foo`); when the unstable flag is used it should be treated as if the stable flag is used.
* When a stable flag is removed because its functionality has been merged into HEAD.

If an unstable flag is removed because the functionality is abandoned, then I think it makes sense to throw an error.

> [@eslint/eslint-tsc](https://github.com/orgs/eslint/teams/eslint-tsc) I think it's worth revisiting the behavior of inactive flags. I had previously brought this up on [#19100 (comment)](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/19100#issuecomment-2457741994), where I suggested that the migration path of flags from unstable to stable to removed may be a bit too sharp. I think it makes sense to emit a warning in these situations instead of erroring:
> 
> * I think it's reasonable that an unstable flag that is removed because the feature has been merged into HEAD.
> * Similarly, when a flag moves from unstable to stable (as in `unstable_foo` -> `v10_foo`); when the unstable flag is used it should be treated as if the stable flag is used.
>  * When a stable flag is removed because its functionality has been merged into HEAD.
> 
> If an unstable flag is removed because the functionality is abandoned, then I think it makes sense to throw an error.

Raising warnings for inactive flags was the only expected behavior before #18705. From a user perspective I think that warnings make more sense than errors in most cases because they don't require restricting the version range of the `eslint` dependency when the status of a flag changes, so I'd be in favor of this change. If you want to switch to warnings before the RFC to pass flags as environment variables suggested in #19100, that would be also fine.

I agree with @nzakas'  https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/19337#issuecomment-2591075029.

What happens in major releases, are we going to remove inactive flags so that trying to use them at that point will be an error?

> What happens in major releases, are we going to remove inactive flags so that trying to use them at that point will be an error?

I was thinking we could just leave inactive flags in place because they don't take up a lot of memory. I'm not opposed to removing them in major releases if that's what everyone wants.

repository.name: dibbs-query-connector
repository.description: A FHIR client allowing public health agencies to query health care organizations directly or via a TEFCA QHIN

issue.title: refactor!: type definitions and usages of @xsai/tool
issue.body:
## BREAKING CHANGE

* Refactor tool-associated type definitions and usages in `@xsai/generate-text`, `@xsai/shared-chat`, and `@xsai/tool`, to unify (slightly) the types scattered in the project
* Merge `result` and `args` from `ToolResult` into `ToolCall` to reduce similar types
* Update types exported by `xsai`

## Other Changes

* Rename `ToolResult` in `packages/tool/src/index.ts` previously to `Tool` to avoid confusion, since it sounds like an interface for the result of a tool invocation
* Remove `unstable_ts_config` from `eslint.options.flags` as per https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/19337

body:
**TSC Summary:** This issue proposes that we change inactive flags to emit warnings instead of errors in these situations:

* An unstable flag becomes inactive because the feature is now enabled by default.
* A stable flag becomes inactive because the feature is now enabled by default.
* A flag moves from unstable to stable. The unstable flag should work just like the stable flag except that it emits a warning.

If an unstable flag is removed because the functionality is abandoned, then it throws an error.

**TSC Questions:** 

1. Should we accept this proposal?
2. Should inactive flags ever be removed?
